profile.name: Yeray
profile.title: Developer at otogami.com
profile.description:
*   Seasoned developer currently working on iOS, Android, and Raspberry Pi applications. Currently programming in these languages: C#, Dart, JavaScript, Kotlin, Python, and Swift. Co-author of _iOS Apprentice, 8th Edition_ and author/presenter of the _Beginning ARKit_ video tutorial series.
*   Mobile technology consultant with experience helping enterprises manage their communications technologies, particularly data networking and mobile devices.
*   Trusted technical evangelist with a strong track record of community building.
*   Dynamic speaker and presenter, comfortable in front of an audience, a camera, or a microphone.
*   Rock accordion/keyboard player with stage, studio, and live television experience.

challenges.description:
Technical marketer and developer evangelist for the company during their pivot from RFID tag/inlay manufacturer to provider of an integrated RFID/cloud software solution to seamlessly connect real-world objects to their digital representations.

*   Product owner: Gathered requirements, and then specified the functionality and workflows for a hardware/software system for embedding RFID tags in luxury goods for tracking them through the manufacturing process and the sales cycle, and as an anti-counterfeiting measure.
*   Led documentation effort and and wrote code examples for Smart Cosmos Objects, Smarttrac’s platform for connecting real-world objects with RFID tags to their cloud-based data representations.
*   Promoted Smartrac to various technical and non-technical audiences, specifically business and technical decision-makers at prospective partners and clients in the medical, supply chain management, and retail industries. Provided technical information to developers at partner organizations (including Catalyst, Blue Bite, and Temera) who build solutions that integrate with the Smart Cosmos platform.
*   Presented the Lifecycles solution at the Smartrac booth at “Retail’s Big Show 2017”, the National Retail Federation’s flagship conference in New York City. Brought a major prospective customer ($100M revenue in 2016) to Smartrac for an initial meeting.

Oversaw and overhauled GSG’s marketing efforts, creating all the messaging and sales materials for the enterprise communications services specialist.

*   Communications and technical specialist on IBM’s Network Infrastructure Cost Optimization team. Designed/managed development of the application for performing quick evaluations of client network infrastructure. Wrote, produced, and narrated the official NICO promotional video, and created all NICO promotional material.
*   Created sales and marketing materials for GSG and its channel partners: presentations, case studies, white papers, sell sheets, videos, and even mobile applications. Created documentation and training material for GSG’s SaaS applications, such as written documentation, demo scripts, and training videos. Wrote and hosted joint presentations and webinars with channel partners, including Honeywell and Pomeroy.
*   Grew GSG’s online presence 10x. Managed their web site redesign, maintained the site’s content, regularly posted articles on the blog, created promotional and informational videos, and expanded the company’s following on LinkedIn (300 to 1,500) and Twitter (100 to 1,100).

Managed a consultancy that became the de facto managed mobility services department of [Rogers Communications](https://www.rogers.com/) (the Canadian equivalent of Time-Warner), filling the roles of chief technologist and marketing department.

*   Designed and developed turnkey solutions for Rogers, including “BYOD in a Box” and “CL in a Box”, applications for small- and medium-sized businesses to manage their BYOD (“Bring Your Own Device”) and CL (corporate-liable) mobile devices. These applications combined mobile device management, telecom expense management, device inventory, and help desk applications.
*   Performed Rogers’ first mobile needs assessments, including one for an energy company in Canada’s far north, which involved on-site visits to their head office in Calgary and their drill site in northern Alberta, interviewing two dozen stakeholder groups in the organization, convening with their IT department, and producing a full report complete with recommendations for increased productivity and cost savings.
*   Implemented processes for clients with 1,000+ employees move from corporate-liable mobile devices to individual-liable ones.
*   Created Rogers-branded customer-facing documents, including a white paper listing tips for businesses who want to implement a BYOD program, a guide to help enterprises create mobile device policies, and “sell sheets” for various Rogers services.

Raised the company’s profile during a critical growth phase, promoted it to three major audiences: merchants who were considering using Shopify to host their ecommerce sites, developers who were considering development of apps for Shopify stores and designers who were considering developing store themes.

*   Managed the company’s first major developer outreach initiative, a $1 million fund used to encourage developers to build apps of the Shopify platform.
*   Wrote the documentation and sample code for Shopify’s developer API, as well as documentation for store theme designers. Edited and wrote technical articles Shopify’s technology blog, whose primary audience was developers and designers.
*   Represented Shopify at a number of conferences, including the [2011 BarCamp Tour](https://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/5/prweb8382118.htm), a multi-city tour of nine BarCamp “unconferences” across the United States.
*   Wrote Shopify’s tweets and doubled the company’s Twitter followers.

Specialized in promoting Microsoft to “unfriendly” technical audiences — namely mobile, web, and open source developers, with whom the company had weak or non-existent relationships. “Won over” developers and technology influencers who originally had strong negative opinions of Microsoft and increased its influence in one of the world’s fastest-growing tech hubs.

*   Windows Phone 7 Champion: Led the “breadth program” for Windows Phone 7 in the months leading up to the release of the new phone operating system. Brought early-access development tools, devices, documentation, and training to developers, coordinated the development of early apps by Canadian developers to pre-seed the Windows Phone app store, and organized Windows Phone developer events.
*   Editor, MSDN Flash: Edited and wrote the lead articles for the Canadian edition of MSDN Flash, Microsoft's developer newsletter emailed every two weeks to 50,000 subscribers.
*   Microsoft Canada’s most prolific blogger: Wrote almost 750 articles for Microsoft’s blog, Canadian Developer Connection.
*   Co-organized TechDays, a conference series taking place in 8 cities across Canada. Organized a conference session in 2008, led one of the developer tracks in 2009, and managed all the developer tracks in 2010.
*   Touring presenter: Traveled across Canada, giving presentations and tutorials to developer, technologist, and student audiences on developing applications using Visual Studio, C# and Visual Basic, Windows 7, ASP.NET MVC, Windows Mobile, Windows Phone, and Xbox 360.
*   Developed example code and demonstrations in C# and Visual Basic for a number of Microsoft platforms, especially Windows 7, ASP.NET MVC, Windows Mobile/Phone, and Xbox 360.

*   Coordinated the activities of the b5 development team in building and maintaining its blog network, a Wordpress-based custom blogging system supporting over 300 blogs.
*   Developed the specification for Textpods, a self-serve system that allows small-budget advertisers to purchase text-link advertising on b5’s blogs.
*   Reviewed, triaged and prioritized of all outstanding projects.
*   Developed utilities in Ruby to automate the process of checking the entire set of b5’s blogs for the presence of important components such as advertising, web statistics codes and blogrolls.

details.name: “Big Event 2020” Apple Watch app
details.description: This app — developed and deployed to the App Store on a Saturday afternoon — shows the scheduled events for the [Synapse Summit](https://synapsefl.com/summit/) 2020 conference, which took place in Tampa on Feb. 11 - 12, 2020. It’s a lot easier to check the schedule on your watch than it is to pull out your phone!

details.name: iOS Apprentice, 8th Edition
details.description: Co-author of “iOS Apprentice, 8th edition,” RayWenderlich.com’s “flagship” book. Completely revised two major sections of the book to cover developing apps using the SwiftUI framework. Rewrote two of the four apps presented in the book to reflect the new material.

details.name: Lilypad (Android version)
details.description: The first Android version of the Lilypad app with my contributions (a lot of bug fixes and performance improvements) was released after my first month on the job. I was one of two programmers working on the mobile app, and most of my responsibilities were with the Android version.

details.name: ARKit by Tutorials
details.description: Technical editor of “ARKit by Tutorials,” a book covering augmented reality app development for iOS devices.

details.name: Aspiration Winery’s Wine Crush
details.description: _Aspirations Winery’s Wine Crush_ is a free iOS app written to promote a friend’s winery and wine shop in Clearwater, Florida. It’s a wine-themed game in the style of Candy Crush, and a promotional tool that other wineries won't have. It's available for free on the App Store. Unlike other free games, there aren't any "poison pills" to extract money from players — this game's just about simple, unadulterated fun.

details.name: Peekabooty
details.description:
Peekabooty was an anti-censorship tool announced by the hacker and do-it-yourself media organization [Cult of the Dead Cow](http://cultdeadcow.com/) at the [DefCon](https://www.defcon.org/) conference in the summer of 2001. It was a peer-to-peer encrypted proxy system that circumvented internet censorship systems such as “The Great Firewall of China”, and has since been supplanted by VPN and similar anti-censorship technologies.

Even though it was announced, the project wasn’t actually implemented until Paul Baranowski and I worked on it starting December 2001, and presented it at the CodeCon conference in February 2002. Paul was the back-end developer, building the underlying networking software, while I was the front-end developer, and built and designed the user interface, which included the cute bear icons that the screen used to show other users on the network.

Peekabooty got a considerable amount of press at the time. Here’s a short list of articles: - _The Register:_ [Censor-buster Peek-A-Booty goes public](http://www.theregister.co.uk/2002/02/18/censorbuster_peeka_booty_goes_public/) - _Neowin:_ [Peek-A-Booty raises a few eyebrows at CodeCon](https://www.neowin.net/news/peek-a-booty-raises-a-few-eyebrows-at-codecon) - From the book _[Hacktivism and Cyberwars: Rebels with a Cause?:](https://www.amazon.com/Hacktivism-Cyberwars-Rebels-Tim-Jordan/dp/0415260043/ref=sr_1_1)_ I am briefly mentioned on page 102 for my involvement with Peekabooty. - _Spiegel Online:_ [Vorhang auf für Peek a Booty:](http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/tech/im-zeichen-des-teddies-vorhang-auf-fuer-peek-a-booty-a-183280.html) Peekabooty, as covered by the online version of the German news magazine _Der Spiegel_.

details.name: Interview on “The 6-Figure Developer” podcast
details.description: In this interview with the podcast _[The 6 Figure Developer](https://6figuredev.com/),_ I talk about working on _iOS Apprentice, 8th Edition,_ iOS development in general, mobile technology in general, and my philosophy for choosing technologies to work on: “Always bet on the tech that’s being dismissed as a toy.”

details.name: Cited in the book “Cult of the Dead Cow How the Original Hacking Supergroup Might Just Save the World” by Joseph Menn (2019)
details.description: Paul Baranowski and I appear at the start of Chapter 9, which covers the _Peekabooty_ application.

image.alt: Cited in the book “Cult of the Dead Cow How the Original Hacking Supergroup Might Just Save the World” by Joseph Menn (2019)

details.name: Full interview on “Thunder Nerds” on Jupyter Notebooks, accordions, and more
details.description: This is a full hour-long interview on the _Thunder Nerds_ podcast where I talk about a recent presentation on Jupyter Notebooks, plus how I got started in programming, and what brought me to the Tampa Bay area.

image.alt: Full interview on “Thunder Nerds” on Jupyter Notebooks, accordions, and more

details.name: Interview on “Thunder Nerds”, DevFest Florida 2019
details.description: This interview was conducted at DevFest Florida 2019, a Google technologies-focused conference at Disney World. I talk about my presentation on using Jupyter Notebooks to make dynamic documents that combine both text and Python programs to create a whole new kind of document.

details.name: ARKit Workshop
details.description: This is the second of TWO presentations I gave at the RWDevCon 2018 conference on developing augmented reality apps with ARKit. I walk the audience through the development of 4 AR apps.

details.name: Getting Started with ARKit with Joey Devilla - Live Tutorial Session - RWDevCon 2018
details.description: This is one of TWO presentations I gave at the RWDevCon 2018 conference on ARKit. This 2-hour session is the shorter presentation, where I teach ARKit by walking through the development of 2 apps: a Bob Ross-inspired “3D painter” app in the spirit of Google’s [Tilt Brush](https://www.tiltbrush.com/) and a scaled-down version of the _IKEA Place_ app.

image.alt: Getting Started with ARKit with Joey Devilla - Live Tutorial Session - RWDevCon 2018

details.name: Interview on “Thunder Nerds”, DevFest Florida 2017
details.description: This interview was conducted at DevFest Florida 2017, a Google technologies-focused conference at Disney World. I talk about my presentation on native Android development for web developers, working at an office after years of remote work, and mobile technologies.

details.name: My “Trucker App” job interview homework assignment
details.description:
We were ninety minutes into a one-hour job interview when the CTO said “We like your _breadth_ of experience. Now we’d like to test your _depth_. If we gave you a quick programming assignment, which would you prefer — writing an iOS app, or an Android app? You should go with the one you’re stronger in.”

I’m a much stronger iOS programmer than an Android one. The smart move would’ve been to answer “iOS,” and be done with it.

Instead, I replied “Yes, but you want a guy who can lead a team of both iOS and Android developers. You really should give me both.”

The CTO raised an eyebrow, gave me a look, made a note on his pad, and said “Hmmm...I think I will.”

This is either a “total baller move” (to borrow a turn of phrase the kids are using these day), or the end of that job prospect. But for the job that they’re trying to fill, taking on that challenge was the right thing to do.

It had been a couple of years since I’d touched C or Objective-C, but after bumping my head once or twice against C-isms (“Oh yeah, pointers”), I got into a groove and a few days later, I had an app that I could show them.

I sent them my project files for the iOS app, along with this “highlight reel” of the app in action, which I made using Camtasia Studio. “Tell me what you think while I work on the Android version.”

And that’s the last I heard from them. Follow-up emails were met with silence. After the 6th email (“If you have any questions or comments about the app, please feel free to contact me”), it became apparent that this was a dead end, and it wouldn’t be worth my while to continue working on the Android version. Perhaps I’ll work on it as a way to sharpen my Kotlin skills.

image.alt: My “Trucker App” job interview homework assignment

details.name: Winning a prize
details.description:
The first of three “Makers Hustle Harder” hackathons run by GM in 2017 was held at Tampa Hackerspace. It was an opportunity for Tampa Bay techies to try their programming chops on GM’s Next Generation Infotainment (NGI) in-car console system.

In about an hour, I came up with, coded, and tested an app called “Fitness Fire Drill”, which acts as a referee for [the classic “fire drill” game you play with friends in a car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fire_drill).

The judges liked the app so much that they invented the “Judges’ Fetish” category simply for the purpose of awarding it a prize.

image.alt: Winning a prize at GM’s “Makers Hustle Harder” hackathon

details.name: Playing “Three Gypsies” with the Jackdaws
details.description:
I _always_ bring my accordion when I’m out for a beer, including when I’m out for a beer at Tampa’s Bay Area Renaissance Festival. While watching the Jackdaws, their guitarist Whiplash saw my accordion and invited me to join them onstage to perform “Three Gypsies” (a.k.a. “The Wraggle-Taggle Gypsies-Oh!”).

I’ve included this video to show that yes, I can win over a crowd, which is actually a useful skill in the tech world.

image.alt: Playing “Three Gypsies” with the Jackdaws at Tampa’s Bay Area Renaissance Festival

details.name: TechCrunch: Accordion Guy Joey DeVilla talks the future of culture and IoT
details.description:
John Biggs invited me to chat on his "Technotopia" podcast, where we talked about my new job at SMARTRAC, RFID and the internet of things, nostalgia, pop culture, and how they intersect with technology, and optimism about the future.

Here’s how he introduced me: Joey DeVilla is my blogging hero. He's run his blog for most of two decades and he's worked at Microsoft, Shopify, and Tucows. Most recently he's taken on the..

image.alt: TechCrunch: Accordion Guy Joey DeVilla talks the future of culture and IoT

details.name: Promo video for “Aspirations Winery’s Wine Crush”
details.description: This video gives you a taste of the app I created for a friend’s winery, best described as “Like that Candy game, but with _wine!_”

image.alt: Promo video for “Aspirations Winery’s Wine Crush”

details.name: Dale Mabry Highway prototype
details.description: This one's a work in progress -- a little "Frogger"/"Crossy Road"-type game for iOS that I'm hoping to put in the App Store later this year. There's still lots to polish, but the basic game mechanics are in place.

details.name: IBM NICO: Network Infrastructure Cost Optimization (IBM version)
details.description:
This 5-minute, 33-second video introduces IBM’s NICO service to the viewer. It explains how your network infrastructure could be costing your organization significantly more than it should, and how NICO can drive down your infrastructure and service costs, identify and fix system issues in your telecom system, and give you the tools and best practices to make the most of your network.

I was the “army of one” behind this video, which I produced when I was the Technology Evangelist at GSG, who are an IBM partner, and provide the software platform and assessment services that go into NICO. I wrote the script, did the narration, gathered or created its images, and produced it — all in the span of a couple of weeks.

image.alt: IBM NICO: Network Infrastructure Cost Optimization (IBM version)

details.name: “Dark Mobile” webinar for Enterprise Mobile (Honeywell)
details.description:
This 13-minute, 12-second video is taken from the “Dark Mobile” webinar that I led for a division of Honeywell formerly known as Enterprise Mobile. “Dark Mobile” is a term that I coined the term during my time at GSG, and it refers to those parts of an enterprise’s mobile telecom environment that goes unobserved, unmanaged, and unknown.

In addition to coming up with the topic and title for the webinar, I wrote the script, hosted the webinar, and produced the video based on the recording and Honeywell’s slides.

details.name: My Ignite Tampa Bay 2015 presentation: A stirring defense of Florida Man and Florida Woman!
details.description:
I gave this presentation -- the second-last of the evening -- at Ignite Tampa Bay 2015, which took place in Tampa's Cuban Club on Thursday, August 27, 2015. In it, I sang the praises of "Florida Man" and "Florida Woman", those staples of slow news days and internet memes, and showed how they're this state's most valuable resource, complete with Florida Man logic and a closing accordion number.

This was a presentation given in the "Ignite" format. It's 5 minutes long, with 20 slides, each slide advancing automatically every 15 seconds. The format has been described as "the presentation equivalent of a haiku or sonnet." They're more challenging than your typical presentation, and require more rehearsal -- and they're also more thrilling to give!

image.alt: My Ignite Tampa Bay 2015 presentation: A stirring defense of Florida Man and Florida Woman!

details.name: Canadian Business: How to have a great relationship with your IT department
details.description:
_Canadian Business_ magazine has a regular “How-To” section that features advice from a expert, and in the July 2015 issue, _I_ was the expert!

Here’s how they introduced me: Joey deVilla, platform evangelist at GSG Telco, shares four tips for how to keep your tech people from phoning it in. A little acknowledgement really helps.

image.alt: Canadian Business: How to have a great relationship with your IT department

details.name: GSG's Mobility 101: Telecom Expense Management, or TEM
details.description:
"Mobility 101" is a series of videos that I put together for [GSG](http://gsgtelco.com) to help the company's partners and their customers understand various aspects of mobile devices, services, applications, and management.

This was my second video for GSG. This one introduces TEM — telecom expense management — in an entertaining way. As with most of these videos, I’m the “army of one” behind it.

image.alt: GSG's Mobility 101: Telecom Expense Management, or TEM

details.name: GSG's Mobility 101: Intro to MMS
details.description:
"Mobility 101" is a series of videos that I put together for [GSG](http://gsgtelco.com) to help the company's partners and their customers understand various aspects of mobile devices, services, applications, and management.

This 8-minute, 19-second video was my first video for GSG. This one explains what MMS is — it’s short for managed mobility services or mobility managed services, depending on whom you ask. As with most of these videos, I’m the “army of one” behind it.

details.name: Startup Weekend Tenerife 2013 winners
details.description: That's it we won.

details.name: Ganador del Startup Weekend Tenerife
details.description: Issued by Startup Weekend Tenerife

details.name: Taking Ford Canada’s C-MAX Holiday Challenge (2012)
details.description:
During the 20102 holiday season, I took a day off from my CTO duties at Comprehensive Technology Solutions/Top Right Corner to participate in the Ford C-MAX Holiday Challenge, where we tried to get maximum efficiency out of Ford's new hybrid vehicles and go toy shopping for charity.

(“Top Right Corner” was a name we were considering to replace “Comprehensive Technology Solutions”, but we never went through with the change.)

image.alt: Taking Ford Canada’s C-MAX Holiday Challenge (2012)

details.name: Introducing the Shopify Fund
details.description: Here’s a 4-minute, 10-second video that I made during my time as a Developer Evangelist at Shopify. This one was aimed at developers, letting them know about the Shopify Fund, a $1 million fund to incentivize developers to build apps for the Shopify ecommerce platform. As with the other videos in this post, this was pretty much me, a microphone, and a laptop with Camtasia Studio and Audacity.

details.name: Announcing the first four Shopify Fund projects (2012)
details.description: A roundup of the first four projects to be funded by the million-dollar Shopify Fund. Written, directed, shot and narrated by Yours Truly.

image.alt: Announcing the first four Shopify Fund projects (2012)

details.name: New Relic's "We Love Developers" Video, featuring Joey deVilla (December 2011)
details.description: This video by New Relic features some of the software world’s brightest lights: Matz, Guido, Linus, DHH, Bill Joy,James Gosling, Sir Tim, Marc, Woz, Rasmus, The Gu, Sergey, Dries and finally Zuck. But guess whose picture they close with at the 1:04 mark!

image.alt: New Relic's "We Love Developers" Video, featuring Joey deVilla (December 2011)

details.name: The time I got Microsoft to sponsor an Android conference because Google wouldn’t
details.description:
In October 2010, Toronto’s [AndroidTO](http://androidto.com/) conference needed a couple of big sponsors to help ensure that they could hold their day-long, hundreds-of-attendees event without losing money. I’d heard that Google wasn’t going to sponsor them, and asked: _\_Why doesn’t Microsoft sponsor them instead?\__

I used the event as an opportunity to showcase Windows as a great development platform for Android, by demoing an HP touchscreen computer set up as an Android development station running Eclipse (which at the time was the preferred Android IDE) and also showing the Windows Phone development environment, which looked a lot less confusing and more aesthetically pleasing than Eclipse (although that’s easy), and showing the C# language (similar to Java, so it seems familiar) and Windows Phone in the process.

image.alt: The time I got Microsoft to sponsor an Android conference because Google wouldn’t

details.name: Windows Phone 7 Showcase in Toronto
details.description:
This video shows the highlights from Microsoft’s Windows Phone 7 Showcase, held one evening in Toronto in September 2010. We put the spotlight on Windows Phone apps created by a number of Toronto-area developers including:

*   Mark Arteaga of Redbit Develeopment
*   Barranger Ridler of 4MK Mobile
*   Alexey Adamsky and Alex Yakobovich of Ryerson University's Digital Media Zone
*   Shawn Konopinsky of Nascent Digital
*   Mike Kasprzak of Sykhronics

I hosted and helped organize this event.

details.name: HTML5 and RIAs: Friends with Benefits
details.description:
When I was a Developer Evangelist at Microsoft, a fellow Microsoftie had a problem: he was buried in work and needed a video comparing HTML with rich internet applications (RIAs) such as Adobe Flash or Microsoft Silverlight. “Can you make one…by tomorrow evening?” he asked. “That’s when I have to show it to this group in Montreal.”

I got to work, and the result is this 5-minute, 46-second piece that summarizes the web world in the summer of 2010. I wrote, designed, narrated, and as the credits say, hastily produced this video, and my coworker was able to present it the following evening.

image.alt: HTML5 and RIAs: Friends with Benefits

details.name: Developer Jr., episode 2: Making movies with Windows Movie Maker
details.description:
Developer Jr. was an all-too-short-lived video series for children ages 7 through 12 that aimed to teach them programming and other creative things they can do with computers and technology. It starred me playing myself, and "Junior", an impish puppet played by Brian Hogg. It was sponsored by Microsoft Canada and produced by Butterscotch.com in early 2010.

In this episode, Junior and I make a simple movie using Windows Movie Maker.

image.alt: Developer Jr., episode 2: Making movies with Windows Movie Maker

details.name: Developer Jr., episode 1: Making games with Kodu
details.description:
Developer Jr. was an all-too-short-lived video series for children ages 7 through 12 that aimed to teach them programming and other creative things they can do with computers and technology. It starred me playing myself, and "Junior", an impish puppet played by Brian Hogg. It was sponsored by Microsoft Canada and produced by Butterscotch.com in early 2010.

In this episode, Junior and I explore basic videogame programming using a Microsoft Labs tool called Kodu.

image.alt: Developer Jr., episode 1: Making games with Kodu

details.name: On the “Developer Jr.” set with Joey deVilla and Junior
details.description: Here’s Butterscotch.com’s Matt Harris interviewing me about “Developer Jr.”, my technology show for kids starring Yours Truly and a puppet, Junior.

image.alt: On the “Developer Jr.” set with Joey deVilla and Junior

details.name: “Byte Club” covers DemoCamp Toronto
details.description:
Byte Club was a series of videos that covered the Toronto tech scene around 2008 and 2009. As a community leader in that scene, I showed up in a number of these videos.

This Byte Club episode covered DemoCamp Toronto, a monthly show-and-tell gathering where Toronto techies could demo their projects in front of an audience of their peers. I was one of the people who co-hosted these gatherings.

You had a time limit to present, and no slides were allowed at DemoCamp — you could only show your project in action!

details.name: “Byte Club” covers b5media
details.description:
Byte Club was a series of videos that covered the Toronto tech scene around 2008 and 2009. As a community leader in that scene, I showed up in a number of these videos.

This was the first Byte Club episode, which covered b5media and featured interviews with the people who ran it, including Yours Truly.

details.name: When to use lambda, when to use Proc.new?
Python: What OS am I running on?
“Byte Club” covers RubyFringe
details.description:
Byte Club was a series of videos that covered the Toronto tech scene around 2008 and 2009. As a community leader in that scene, I showed up in a number of these videos.

This Byte Club episode featured the RubyFringe conference, a very offbeat conference that featured some of the bright lights of the Ruby community, including Obie Fernandez, Zed Shaw, Dan Grigsby, Hampton Catlin, Pete Forde, and Yours Truly!

details.name: Performing
details.description: Upon seeing my accordion, RailsConf 2007 organizer Chad Fowler invited me to come up with a number that we could both perform at the keynote — me on accordion, him on ukulele. Here’s the result: a parody of Radiohead’s “Creep”, re-done as a tribute to Rails creator David Heinemeier Hansson and the “Depot” Rails tutorial.

image.alt: Performing at the RailsConf 2007 evening keynote

image.alt: Cited in the book “Hacktivism and Cyberwars: Rebels with a Cause?” by Tim Jordan and Paul A. Taylor (2004)

details.name: Mackerel: Burying the Fish
details.description: This is an unpublished story that [Cory Doctorow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cory_Doctorow) wrote for _Wired_ about Mackerel Interactive Multimedia, a Toronto-based scrappy upstart multimedia company during the era of the CD-ROM. I’m featured prominently in it.
